data.text: Overview

This document outlines the best practice guidance for providing information about the audit of cases of cervical cancer to the individuals concerned. It does not cover the review of the clinical material which is covered in the NHSCSP publication  “Audit of Invasive Cervical Cancer” (2007). This guidance is based on the advice provided by the NHSCSP in their publication “Disclosure of audit results in cancer screening” (2006) and existing local policies and good practice highlighted during cervical screening QA Team visits.

The guideline outlines what information should be offered, when and how to disclose this information, and the responsibilities of all individuals involved. It is the responsibility of the diagnosing Trust to ensure that the patient is informed about audit and disclosure and ideally the diagnosing clinician  should be responsible for deciding the appropriate occasion to discuss this for each individual patient.

For the purposes of clarity, in women who have a final cervical cancer diagnosis, a retrospective review of the screening history is conducted which includes cytology, histology and colposcopy findings. Primary care information may also be used to supplement the review where appropriate, for example in instances where there may be a gap in the cervical cytology history, to confirm whether relevant symptoms were reported by the patient and to verify previous screening invitations and results via “Open Exeter” although this is no longer a mandatory requirement of the national audit process.

This document applies equally to Hospital based co-ordinators, colposcopists, cancer nurse specialists and any other relevant staff involved with the review and disclosure of the invasive audit results.
This document complies with the Trust's equality policies.

It is the responsibility of staff to ensure that all women diagnosed as having cervical cancer are given the option of being informed of the results of a review on all clinical material reported by cytology and histology laboratories. This includes assessments undertaken by the colposcopy service(s) at individual Trusts.
This document may also include clinical materials held at other trusts including supplemental information obtained from the patients general practice records.

This document is to be adhered to for all patients who are initially diagnosed with cervical cancer at Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust or Basildon and Thurrock University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust irrespective of route of diagnosis, stage or type.
The document does not include patients with recurrent disease or metastatic disease. These patients are not to be offered disclosure.

data.text: Clinical  Director,  Clinical  Lead  for  Obstetrics  &  Gynaecology  and Consultant Obstetricians & Gynaecologists

The Clinical Director for Women and Children's Services along with the Clinical Lead for Obstetrics & Gynaecology and the Consultant Obstetrician & Gynaecologists must ensure that all clinical staff are aware of the Colposcopy Clinical guideline. They are responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the speciality.
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director:

The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she  is  responsible  for  ensuring  that  the  monitoring  and  audit  of  this  document  is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non- medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Director:

The Divisional Clinical Director is responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Division to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Manager

The Divisional General Manager is responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Head of Midwifery & Gynaecology, Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses

The  Head of  Midwifery  &  Gynaecology  is  responsible,  along  with  the  Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses for the implementation of this guideline within the speciality.
Gynaecology Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers:

Gynaecology Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the specialty and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the speciality comply with the contents of this document and for  taking  action  when  this  is  not the  case.  The  Lead  Nurse  will  make  sure  that  all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Cervical Screening Provider Lead (CSPL) (previously known as ‘Hospital Based Programme Co-ordinator (HBPC)'
The CSPL is responsible for ensuring all newly diagnosed cases of invasive cervical cancer are audited in line with NHSCSP guidance.

Notification of new cases to the CSPL is via minutes of the Gynaecological Oncology MDT. When a new case of invasive cancer is identified the CSPL is responsible for triggering the audit process and notifying the QARC.
The CSPL is then responsible for managing the audit process of any Cytology, Histology and Colposcopy reviews undertaken, and ensuring that the audit results are uploaded onto the QARC database.

The CSPL is responsible for obtaining reviews of any slides from other Trusts that may be needed for the audit. Results of these reviews must be included in the audit report, as must any reviews done externally to the Trust.

A summary report of the case audit is produced by the CSPL and sent to the relevant Consultant Gynaecologist and lead Colposcopist, for discussion at the Gynaecology Oncology and/or Colposcopy MDT prior to any disclosure being made.
Lead Colposcopist
Undertakes audit of colposcopy appointments, or arranges for another accredited Colposcopist to undertake the audit if they were involved in the original appointments.
Consultant Gynaecologist/Oncologist

The Consultant Gynaecologist is responsible for informing the woman that the audit review will be carried out, and for subsequent disclosure of the audit information, to be carried out within the framework of the Trust's clinical governance protocols. It should be noted that the audit report constitutes an NHSCSP audit and although it can form the basis of information for disclosure it is NOT a legal case review.

Once treatment is completed the Consultant in charge of the case should also write to the screening office to remove the woman from the call/recall system as further management is outside the scope of the cervical screening programme.
Regional Quality Assurance Reference Centre (QARC)
QARC are responsible for collating all regional cases on their database and submitting annually to the Cancer Research UK national database.

The purpose of audit in a cancer screening programme is to monitor the effectiveness of the programme and to identify areas of good practice and areas for improvement. Audit of personal screening histories may help to identify why an invasive cancer has occurred, despite the individual having previously participated in that screening programme. Some individuals may wish to be informed of the outcome of this audit while others may not.

This guidance aims to ensure that all women diagnosed with a cervical cancer will be given the option of being informed of the results of a review on all clinical material reported by the laboratory (cytology and histology) and assessments undertaken by the colposcopy service(s) at individual Trusts. This may also include material held at other hospitals where this can be obtained. The audit may also be supplemented with information obtained from general practice records.

It is important that clear agreement is reached between organisations, and that written procedures are in place especially where more than one Trust is treating an individual, for example where a Trust routinely refers into a tertiary centre. In these cases it is still recommended that patient is seen by the diagnosing clinician to discuss their review.
The  CSPL compiles the information obtained from cytology, histology, colposcopy and primary care using the Midlands & East (East) of England data collection forms.

A summary of the outcome of the review is produced by the CSPL, sent to the clinicians responsible for treating the patient, and stored on the Clinical Electronic Document (CED) electronic patient record under the heading of Cervical Cancer Audit and is available for viewing at any time. In the event that the information cannot be added to the CED system it will be stored on the Electronic Medical Record (EMR) system under Correspondence at BTUH or the CED under cervical cancer audit at SUHFT.
Who should be offered the results of a screening history review following the diagnosis of cervical cancer?

All women diagnosed with cervical cancer will be offered the results of the review of their screening history unless they have no previous screening history or their most recent history is more than  years prior to diagnosis, in which case old samples will have been destroyed. In other situations, for example if the woman is terminally ill and unlikely to cope with the information, appropriate judgement should be exercised and the reason for not offering the audit results documented clearly in the patient notes.
When to inform the patient about audit

If the patient has had a previous Colposcopic assessment, she will have received a leaflet that states that in the case of a cervical cancer being detected, a review will be carried out and that she can be informed of the results if she wishes.
The initial consultation when results of diagnosis are given is not an appropriate to discuss audit and review unless the patient asks questions about their screening history.

Ideally, discussion of the review of previous screening history and the option of disclosing results of the review will be initiated by the diagnosing clinician or clinical nurse specialist at a subsequent consultation, after treatment has concluded. The audit information leaflet can then be discussed.

The clinician or nurse should ensure that the patient understands the information that has been given, that reviews of all previous screening histories are carried out and that the patient can be given these results if they wish. A consent form for patients covering this process is strongly encouraged so that a clear audit trail exists regarding their consent, or otherwise, to being informed about the results of audit.
Patients who do not wish to receive their review results

Where patients express a wish not to receive the results from the review of their screening history, they should be told that they can change their mind at any point and that if they subsequently choose to know the results, they should contact their consultant, to make the necessary arrangements.
Disclosure of audit results
Where patients express a wish to be informed of the results of their personal screening history review, the following protocol should be followed:
normally, the clinician treating the patient should carry out the consultation
in  the  case  of  an under  reported  cervical  cytology or  histology  report  or under treatment in colposcopy, it is important to;
check the patient's understanding of why she has asked for the information
ascertain how much the patient wishes to know
discuss the relevant reports and implications
invite the patient to voice her comments and concerns before moving on
patients should be helped to understand the reason for any missed abnormality or potential under treatment
the  effectiveness  and  limitations  of  the  screening  programme  described  in  the information leaflet can be referred to
apologies  and  explanations,  as  opposed  to  admissions  of  liability,  are  to  be encouraged
at the time of disclosure, patients should not be assured of a right to compensation but rather of the right to have the issue investigated further should they wish
patients who say they wish to complain or seek compensation should be given first step information as to how to proceed

After the consultation, the clinician should write up the discussion and should send an outline of the discussion to the patient and GP and upload to CED/ Electronic Medical records (EMR) which would need to be undertaken by colposcopy administration staff.
Ongoing audit
Feedback from individual patient discussions should be given, and minuted, at the next available colposcopy multi-disciplinary team meeting; this will be a standing item on the MDT agenda.

Should any issues come to light during reviews that could indicate a potential screening incident, the Midlands & East (East) of England Cervical Screening QA Reference Centre should  be  informed  immediately  so  that  appropriate  advice  can  be  given,  in  line  with NHSCSP guidelines on the management of potential screening incidents. This includes situations where it is considered that litigation is very likely.
Local Trust policies on incident reporting and litigation issues should be followed in addition under these circumstances

data.text: All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Women's Health Policy Steering Group at BTUH or the Gynaecology Practice Group at SUHFT, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local maternity and gynaecology speciality guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Controlled Document Approval Manager/Group for noting or, when there are new guidelines, submission to the Controlled Document Approval Group (CDAG). Policies relevant to more than one Trust will be submitted to the Joint Document Management group. The Women's Health Clinical Governance & Risk Group and / or the Gynaecology Practice group will be notified of approved guidelines and when they are uploaded to the Controlled Document Centre on the relevant Trust intranet.
Implementation

This document will be available electronically on the Trust intranet and staff will be informed of any updates via the intranet. Hard copies of the policy will be available via designated hard copy libraries in accordance with the Controlled Documents policy.
